titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Willets and Edmund lease 1977.627
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-18 21:20:16 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection contains a lease between Edmund Willets and Henry Remsen, dated February 14, 1829, for a two-story dwelling in New York City.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This document has broken into two pieces and should be handled with special care.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Willets and Remsen lease, 1829, 1977.627, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains a lease between Edmund Willets and Henry Remsen, dated February 14, 1829, for a two-story dwelling in New York City. The lease was filed at the New York City Register's Office.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
